awd_titl_txt: Meaningful Math: News Media for Increasing Adult Statistical Literacy
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings.

Familiarity with statistical and data literacy is important in many areas of modern life, but there is little research on how adults continue to build mathematical literacy beyond formal schooling. Mass media science news stories contain much data, assuming that adults will understand the content.This 4-year project will first map the landscape of adult statistical literacy in the US, particularly as it relates to news consumption. The second phase will build on results from the first phase through a longitudinal study. In the third phase, the project will develop a range of experiments to manipulate mathematical explainers embedded in STEM news stories and test techniques with adult audiences, with the goal of identifying the attributes and affordances that best improve confidence and competence in the underlying math principles and their meaning to news stories. in addition to the research, project components include 12 broadcast video and social media pieces each year that will form the basis for testing with audiences, a one-day symposium for professional science journalists, and a written best practice guide that summarizes key findings and implications for practitioners.   

Critical research questions are:  How do mathematical competence and confidence differ among different segments of the adult population? How can STEM journalists improve adult mathematical competence and confidence through their reporting techniques? Phase 1 of the research will be a landscape review of mathematical content in the news including a baseline study of adult statistical literacy. Phase 2 will be a longitudinal study with news audiences recruited to participate in a panel study. Phase 3 will be iterative testing of the digital content based on the findings from Phases 1 and 2 and will use both focus groups and online testing. External evaluation will be conducted by TERC including an evaluation of the symposium for professional journalists.

The broader impacts of this project are twofold: the science videos created will be broadcast and made available free to a national audience including those in rural areas; and the training of science journalists has the potential for multiple, long term impact by increasing their ability to communicate statistics meaningfully to their readers/viewers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For Grant #1906802, "Meaningful Math: News Media for Increasing Adult Statistical Literacy," PBS News and Knology partnered together to build an understanding of the relationship between journalism and public quantitative reasoning (QR), where journalists serve as informal educators through their use of numbers.

Intellectual merit

Together, our team laid out a research agenda that draws attention to the intersections of journalism and math (Barchas-Lichtenstein, Voiklis, Santhanam et al. 2021). We found that health and economic coverage have a very high density of quantitative information, particularly in comparison with science and politics coverage (Voiklis et al., 2022). Our team also identified a number of specific strategies for making these content areas more accessible (Barchas-Lichtenstein, Voiklis, Attaway, et al., 2024; Knology & PBS NewsHour, n.d.).

While it is widely assumed that adult QR — adults’ ability to make sense of and reason with numbers they experience —  is linked to their news routines and preferred sources, we tested this assumption empirically. We found that news sources and formal education explain a surprisingly small amount of the variation between adults, which suggests a number of open questions for further research (Attaway, Voiklis, et al., 2023). 

The team has also developed a theory of how people share news, regardless of what platform they are using (Barchas-Lichtenstein, 2023), and is finalizing a model of how adults make sense of, and learn from, news content in general (Voiklis, Barchas-Lichtenstein, & Attaway, in preparation). 

The news production team has revamped many of their newsroom practices, including shifts in visualization templates, to put the findings to use in hundreds of news stories reaching cumulative millions of people. One thread that crosses many of our findings is that more transparency about methods and uncertainty in numbers can increase trust in communicators, which in turn supports the public's ability to reason with numbers.

Broader Impacts

During the time of this grant, using funding from NSF and other funders, the NewsHour aired many hundreds of science broadcast segments and digital articles, which altogether earned 65.3 million video views and 39.8 million page views on all its platforms. Those metrics are in addition to the almost two million viewers that the program reaches nightly, who could catch the broadcast segments as they aired. The main NSF-relevant topics covered were space, the environment, biology, technology and archeology. We also covered the struggles faced by women and marginalized groups in STEM fields and acknowledged their achievements. While scripting segments, we paid close attention to all we learned while researching math literacy, and worked to ensure that math concepts and indeed numbers that were included conformed to our best practices. Beyond the science segments we produced, the work we conducted around math literacy also engaged with content in other fields – including health, economics and politics. The NewsHour adapted how it visually represented polls to make concepts such as margin of error clearer.

 The most significant achievement of this grant was the launch in May 2023 of  "Reporting With Numbers: Your Guide to Math in Journalism" (https://www.reportingwithnumbers.com/), a living document and best practice guide (Knology and PBS NewsHour, 2023) that has been shared throughout many journalism spaces. The day we launched the site, we held a webinar that was promoted through various professional organizations and contacts. Over 70 people attended, including journalists at highly-regarded media outlets/publications and professors and students at a range of universities. 

PBS News reaches almost two million nightly TV viewers and has almost eight million monthly website visitors; changes in newsroom practice ultimately impact all of them. In parallel to the changes we've made, we have seen similar changes in how our polling partners at NPR represent the results.

In addition, our research findings have been widely shared at journalism conferences and in the journalism trade press (e.g. Benton, 2022), as well as in discussions among professionals on X/Twitter and other social media.

More information on resulting research can be found at  https://knology.org/article/meaningful-math/; all PBS NewsHour sciene is compiled at pbs.org/newshour/science.
